title: Barbarian Days
author: William Finnegan
content:
I really enjoyed this book. It fills you with a sense of child-like adventure. Finnegan spent his life scratching his itch for surfing. Chasing the best waves in the world. Along the way its clear he kept detailed journals. Because the depth he goes into when telling stories from his childhood and young adult years is what makes the book so great. It's an autiobiography, but the quality of the storytelling lends an element of fiction to it as well (as with all good biographies). 

Finnegan grew up in California but the family moved to Hawaii at a young age. Both great surfing destinations of course, and Hawaii seems to be the place that he really came into his own as an independent surfer. After leaving school and being in and out of university, he set off on a mission to circumnavigate the world, chasing the globes best waves with a friend of his, Bryan. After about 2 years of doing exactly that, he settled down in South Africa for a while to teach at a school and surf some of the local waves. Eventually he moved back home to California where he tells stories of the undergroud surfing scene there that most are unaware of. The book finishes up with him in New York, writing full time as a journalist and often running off to New York's (much colder) waves.

Throughout the book a few things stick out.

**A "way of life"**: The love of surfing has been a rare constant throughout his life. Over 40 years since starting, he will still drop what he is doing at a moment's notice and run off with a wetsuit to catch a wave in the freezing cold seas of New York. It really makes you want to find your own passion, whatever your own version of surfing is. 

**Risking it all for a wave**: Along a similar vein, the risks of injury that himself and his friends often took is impressive. A lifelong passion yes. But never anything more than the next wave. Surfers dont look at the sport as a whole very often. Instead they think "is it worth it for this wave?". The answer is almost always yes.

**Surfing friendships**: Finnegan made new friends through surfing from the age of 14 all the way through to 40. Never short of a kind person to share the sport with.

**Growth through travel**: By meeting new people and seeing new cultures, he clearly developed a new way of looking at the world. A more complete one. In moving to Hawaii with his family he had left western culture. And travelling in his 20s simply continued to widen his perspective. 

**Always writing**: This may not surprise many people, but as a budding writer and journalist he was always writing. Journals for his personal use. Articles for travel and surf magazines. A novel of his own. This shouldn't surprise that many, but it's worth noting that, as usual, the best way to do what you want to do professionally is to do a shit-load of it non-professionally first. There's rarely a short cut.

title: The Proud Highway
author: Hunter S Thompson
content:
I really enjoyed this. Thompson is a breath of fresh air and this comes through nowhere more clearly than in his letters. It's rare that the history of someones writing is documented so well from the early years of their life (this book starts with letters he wrote at 17, and ends in his 30s).

It's certainly not the perfect example of how to live. He continued to make the same mistakes many times, and made a lot of decisions that happened to work out for him but probably wouldn't in most cases. 

That being said, it is certainly a lesson in living. You can't help but be inspired to do something more outrageous and different in your life as a result of reading the views of this man. 

Favourite quotes below:

# Work
- "Gonzo, he wrote, “is a style of ‘reporting based on William Faulkner’s idea that the best fiction is far more true than any kind of journalism"
- "Also, without the slightest exaggeration, I drink approximately 20 cups of coffee every 24 hours and manage to sleep about 5 hours a night."
- "Instead of battling my environment, I enjoy my work tremendously and put in about 15 hours a day at it—for the simple reason that I like to write."
- "I just keep wandering around, doing all these things and not worrying about what the results will be. So far it’s turned out pretty well."
- "I shall slave like an animal until my present run of good fortune and luck runs on the rocks. It seems impossible that it could be a lasting thing."
- "Keep in mind that the ability to create is an integral part of the makeup of man."
- "The pay is miserable, of course, but the work might be interesting."
- "Thompson polished his writing skills by typing The Great Gatsby and A Farewell to Arms in their entirety, closely studying their sentence structures." - *Focused hard worker*
- "Needless to say, I do not seek a job, but rather a position or a connection. Nor do I particularly seek money, except in the form of having my expenses covered in what I undertake"
- "I am half mad from the silence I have imposed upon myself in Woody Creek, and when I find myself among human beings I tend to explode."
- "Whether you are a journalist or not, the only way to attempt journalism is to assume you know nothing at the start, and then only write what you find evidence to support"
- "Right now I should be writing my new “column” in Ramparts, but I can’t get up the zap for it." -*Proof he never works, just does what he loves and gets paid for it*

# Life Experience
- "Who is the happier man, he who has braved the storm of life and lived, or he who has stayed securely on shore and merely existed?"
- "Has he any self-respect or pride in himself? How could he, when he has risked nothing and gained nothing?"
- "How does he feel when he realizes that he has barely tasted the meal of life; when he sees the prison he has made for himself in pursuit of the almighty dollar?"
- "A man is to be pitied who lacked the courage to accept the challenge of freedom and depart from the cushion of security and see life as it is in stead of living it second-hand."
- "These are the insignificant and forgotten men who preach conformity because it is all they know."
- "who is the happier man, he who has braved the storm of life and lived or he who has stayed securely on shore and merely existed?"
- "You’ve lived a relatively narrow life, a vertical rather than a horizontal existence." - *Explore vs exploit*
- "I’ll stop trying to convince myself that I can’t fail: how dull the whole thing would be if that were true."
- "the most overriding of all human desires is the need to amount to something."
- "If only for an instant, the image of the man is imposed on the chaotic mainstream of life and it remains there forever:"
- "I’ve learned the difference by now between a good and a bad risk."
- "Let’s face it: any man who really wants to work for Burdorf Furniture—or its equivalent—for the rest of his life is bound to be crazy—or a terribly narrow-minded coward."
- "get old gracefully—not like a boob, but like a champion."
- "I’ll go as far as the rides take me, sleep on the beach (sleeping bag), and beg, if necessary, for food."
- "Never crusading for their ideas, but doing their utmost to put them into practice" - *Live dont preach*
- "What the fuck have you done except get rich?"
- "Let’s face it—it’s the tension of life that keeps the light in a man’s eyes, and keeps the foam in his nuts. It’s really the only thing you can’t afford to lose."
- "But it took me six months, on horses, boats, jeeps and bush planes, to get from New York to Rio. And believe me, there is a difference."
- "**There is an amazing amount of resentment, among aging hacks, toward a young hotshot trying to bypass the bullshit jobs that none of them could avoid.**"
- "I’m beginning to feel the old action mania, the compulsion to get where things are happening."
- "Now I shoot clay pigeons off the porch. And I do a lot of wood-work — shelves, walls, etc." - *Hobbies*

# Individuailty
- "A man who lacks the ability to think for himself is as useless as a dead toad, while the thinking man has all the powers of the universe at his command."
- "Loneliness is for people who can’t see themselves except through the eyes of their compatriots, and all evidence points to the fact that I’ve passed that stage."
- "Anyone who doesn’t need other people to feed his ego can find privacy anywhere."
- "And indeed, that IS the question: whether to **float with the tide, or to swim for a goal**. It is a choice we must all make—consciously or unconsciously—at one time in our lives."
	- "Existentialism: From Dostoyevsky to Sartre."
	- "we must make the goal conform to the individual, rather than make the individual conform to the goal."
	- "a man must choose a path which will let his ABILITIES function at maximum efficiency toward the gratification of his DESIRES."
	- "but he has rather chosen a way of life he KNOWS he will enjoy."
- "There is plenty of money in the world but there are damn few jobs an intelligent man can do without compromising himself intolerably."
- "If you change yourself in order to be loved, then you are in love with love and not a person."
- "we are all alone, born alone, die alone,"
- "I don’t see how you can respect yourself if you must look in the hearts and minds of others for your happiness."
- "To be nobody-but-yourself—in a world which is doing its best, night and day, to make you somebody else—means to fight the hardest battle which any human being can fight; and never stop fighting. * that’s e. e. cummings,"
- "My position is and always has been that I distrust power and authority, together with all those who come to it by conventional means"
- "nobody—despite the advertisements—has whipped up the dish you know you want to taste."
- "Most people wind up going against their instincts, and it makes them miserable for the rest of their lives."
- "I’ve also learned at least one crucially important thing since then. And that’s the idea of making your own pattern, not falling into grooves that other people made."
- "the secret of not getting caught in it is to have something of your own … some kind of skill or talent or action that other people have to respect. That way, you can ride when you want, and back off when you want."
- "**be an outlaw … but do it your own way, for your own reasons**, and for christ’s sake don’t blow it as badly as the Angels have."


# Party
- "It should be interesting … if nothing else."
- "I’m going to need that carnival to clear my system and present plans call for me to hit the docks with one toothbrush, no extra clothes and whatever money I can scrape together. I intend to sleep on the beach (impossible to get reservations even if I could afford them) and suck up every ounce of drink I can get my hands on. I’ll probably be arrested several times, flogged by the police, and will undoubtedly have to steal a boat to get back to San Juan. I would certainly not be able to keep a steady eye on you and I know damn well that’s what I’d have to do if you were with me."
- "With the Rogue money I bought a pistol and a Doberman and a lot of whiskey,"
- "I have found that most people harbor a real fear of having a little piece of lead blasted through their flesh & the drunker I get the more it amuses me."
- "If I had my way I’d be in love all the time all over the world with a rifle in one hand and a typewriter in the other and a bellyful of good whiskey."
- "Besides that, I seem to be doing everything humanly possible to finish myself with booze and general physical abuse, pills, no sleep, etc."
- "As for LSD, I highly recommend it. We had a fine, wild weekend and no trouble at all. The feeling it produces is hard to describe. “Intensity” is a fair word for it."
- "I have paid first $40 and then $50 for season tickets to the San Francisco 49er games during the past two years…" - *Loved sports*

# Writing
- "words are such a poor medium when you really want someone to feel something."
- "This is merely the first of a series of lectures on “subjects Thompson needs to get straight in his mind.”"
- "I find that by putting things in writing I can understand them and see them a little more objectively"
- "For words are merely tools and if you use the right ones you can actually put even your life in order, if you don’t lie to yourself and use the wrong words."
- "Well, this has been a good excuse for not working on the novel for an hour or so." - *Spent hours writing letters*

# Poverty
- "Where I’m going to get the money to go bouncing around the country like this is a real interesting problem: but I shall find it somewhere. I’ll have to."
- "I simply have no money at all"
- "At the moment I have three dollars to my name, a can of tuna fish and a can of soup in the cabin, no oil for the furnace, one bag of dried food for the dog, and about enough gas in the Jaguar to make it back to that freezing hellhole for the night." - *He was seriously broke*
- "the duffel bag and the box and the books and anything else" - *All he owns*
- "I have made $630 in the past six weeks. I am so used to poverty that I can waste most of it and not know the difference."

# Relationships
- "I think you should know my downs as well as my ups. The carefree Thompson facade gets very tiresome at times, and I need to have someone with whom I can be honestly confused and lost."
- "I can hardly be civil to women, and told a girl last night that if I came home with her the only act I would perform would be that of throwing her child off the cliff and into the sea."
- "send a line and say what you think. I’d really like to know how my style strikes you on various pieces." - *Opening a channel for relationship*

# Self Belief
- "Perhaps I’ll try to publish my collected letters before, instead of after, I make history."
- "There is some that makes it, and some that don’t. I just happen to think I’m going to make it. I couldn’t afford to think otherwise."
- "my time is too valuable to waste in an effort to supply the “man in the street” with his daily quota of clichés, gossip, and erotic tripe."

- "There is no question that I have honed my skills to the point of unbelievable sharpness."

- "I explained that I wasn’t in the habit of settling my beefs with my fists, but with a double-barreled 12-gauge shotgun."
- "In closing, all I can say is don’t let the bastards scare you. We are tougher than they want us to think. HST"

# Books

- "It is a novel more gripping than The Ginger Man, more skillfully rendered than The Sergeant, more compassionate than James Agee’s A Death in the Family, and more important than Lie Down in Darkness. These, as you know, are the only good novels written in the past five years."

That is exactly the way I feel."

title: Mindset
author: Carol Dweck
content:
> All about moving from "judge and be judged" thinking to "learn and help learn" thinking

Some good quotes
- "Why waste time proving yourself over and over when you can focus on getting better"
- "The passion for stretching yourself and sticking to it when things arent going well"
- "Becoming is better than being"
- "Whats heroic about being born gifted?"
- "Picture your brain forming new connections and pathways as you learn"
- "You dont have to already be good at something to enjoy doing it"
- "Mental toughness and hard work are stronger than any physical advantages you may have"
- "Improving, not proving"
- "Problems can be a vehicle to greater understanding and intimacy"
- "Keep setting goals for growth"

### The Mindsets
- Your mindset
	- We are all a mix of fixed/growth mindsets
	- In some areas we are growth, in others we are fixed

| Growth | Fixed |
| --- | --- |
| = You can cultivate your qualities through effort | = Your qualities are fixed/inherent |
| Risk and effort improve you | Risk and effort reveal your inadequacies, in the growth mindset they improve you |
| Success is about learning | Sucess is about proving youre smart |
| Failure is an action (I failed) | Failure is an identity (I am a failure) |
| Dont let failure define them, instead take control of it| Let failure define them |
| Risk = Low Effort (missed potential) | Risk = High Effort (Risk exposing inability), should not need to try, **Low effort syndrome** = Dont try so you cant be measured |
| People love what they are doing regardless of the outcome| Creates a need to prove yourself |
| Accept some imperfections - Not everything that can be changed should be changed | Self worth over invested in outcomes |
| | Thrive on safety and comfort |
| | Need to be perfect, and to be perfect immediately |
| | Need **validation** that you are special |
| | Tendency to LIE |

### Effort vs Ability
- Effort > Ability
- Accomplishment comes from effort
- Your heroes worked really hard
	- If you ever doubt this, research how hard any of your heroes worked
- People that beat you worked hard
	- They used better learning strategies
	- They thought about the problem longer
	- They practised harder
- GM: Other people are **allied not judges**
- FM: Vulnerable to others comments (value their opinion over your own)
- Praise effort not ability (better to develop growth mindset)
- Learning is more important than grades
- Effort and learning neurologically transform your brain

### Mindset in Sports
- Characteristics of champions
	- **Character** = Ability to dig deep and find strength when times get really hard
		- React well to setbacks (dig deep)
		- Use past experiences as proof you can do it
	- *Love practise*** and putting in the work (love the process)
	- All champions in sport **work insanely hard**
- "Somebody-Nobody syndrome" = If I win I'm a somebody, if I lose i'm a nobody
- Examples of sportsmen whos effort got them to the top
	- Muhammed Ali - Failed the measurements that usually defined great boxers
	- Michael Jordan - Hardest worker in history of sport, cut from his High School team
- Research findings
	1. Success
		- Growth: Successs is about learning (good winner)
		- Fixed: Success is about establishing superiority (bad winner)
	2. Failure
		- Growth: Learning experience (good loser)
		- Fixed: Setbacks label you (bad loser)
	3. Process
		- Growth: Took control of the process (internal Locus of Control)
		- Fixed: Blamed external circumstances (external locus of control)

### Mindset in Business
- Good companies have leaders with growth mindsets
- Good leaders are made, not born
- Qualities of a leader

| Growth | Fixed |
| --- | --- |
| Learning focussed | Talent focussed |
| Good company | Bad company |
| Humble | Arrogant |
| Leader = Guide | Leader = God |
| Secure | Insecure |
| Fosters disagreement | Avoids disagreement |
| Improves ability | Proves superiority |
| "We" and "us" language | "I" and "Me" language |
| Teams | Individuals |
| Equality | Elitism |
| | Cannot imagine being wrong |


### Mindset in Relationships
- Some people let past relationships scar them and prevent them from forming satisfying relationships in the future. Others are able to heal and move on
- **Rejection**
	- Fixed
		- Feel judged and labeled by the rejection ("I am unlovable")
		- Judge yourself --> Blame yourself
	- Growth: Understand the rejection, focus on **forgiving, learning and moving on**
- 3 beliefs of the fixed mindset in a relationship (in GM they can be developed)
	1. Your own qualities are fixed
	2. Your partners qualities are fixed
	3. The relationships qualities are fixed
- Two problems with FM in relationships
	1. "If you have to work at it, it wasnt meant to be"
		- It should not require effort, if it does then it wasnt meant to be (low effort syndrome)
		- My partner should be able to know what im thinking (mindreading)
	2. Problems indicate character flaws
		- In the FM: Conflict --> Blame --> Blame a trait/characteristic
		- People with GM accept partners imperfections
		- FM believes flaws are permanent --> Much worse
		- GM thinks they can be changed --> Flaws not so bad
			- "Problems can be a vehicle to greater understanding and intimacy"
- **Blame**
	- FM always looks to assign blame
	- GM tries to rise above blame, understand the problem and work on it
- **Friendship**
	- FM desire to prove yourself bad for friendship
	- I put you down so I feel big --> Bad for friendship
	- Comes from FM need to prove itself
	- FM seeks validation from their friends
	- 2 questions for a friendship
		1. When things are bad, who can I turn to for support
		2. When things are good, who can I turn to for congratulations/will be glad to hear it
- **Social interactions**
	- Shyness comes from FM being concerned about judgement
	- GM welcomes the chance to meet someone new --> Less shy/anxious
	- "Social interactions are for learning and enjoyment"

### Mindsets in Parenting/Teaching/Coaching
- Coaching
	- Growth: You are a growing person and I am committed to your development
	- Fixed: You have fixed traits and I am judging them
- Praise effort and the process, not intelligence
- Set high standards **and** provide a means of reaching them (challenge + nurture)
- Teach, dont judge
- Be honest
	- Sometimes they dont deserve to win, but dont lie to them and say they do
	- Tell the truth and give them the tools to improve
- Beware the "disease of me"
	- The more you win, the more you get into a fixed mindset ("i have a gift")
- Have a growth mindset about your coaching ability
- Beware the fake growth mindset
	- Only praising hard work
	- In reality you need to work smart and hard
	- Try new strategies and approaches

### Changing Mindsets
- Change is a long process of removing old traits and adding new ones, it takes time
- Cognitive therapy
	- Look at your self judgements
	- Make them more reasonable
	- Judging --> Learning and growing
- Good traits to cultivate
	- Determination
	- Work ethic
	- Kindness
	- Focus
- People develop a fixed mindset as children beacuse it benefitted them somehow
	- How did the FM benefit me as a child? --> I was best at everything to fell into the "disease of me" trap
- Make a concrete plan of steps toward change
- Thoughts that prevent change
	1. Entitlement - The world owes me and I shouldnt have to change for it
	2. Denial - My life is perfect right now and I dont need to change
- Mindset and willpower
	- Willpower alone is not enough
	- We must use the growth mindset to develop strategies for coping with bad times too
	- FM = good/bad, strong/weak thinking
- Judge and be judged --> Learn and help learn
- Journey
	1. Accept your FM
	2. Notice your FM triggers (someone better than you)
	3. Give your FM a name
	4. Educate it on why it is bad for you, begin disputing it
	5. Keep setting goals for growth
- Keep setting goals for growth

title: Siddartha
author: Herman Hesse
content:
%%Buddhism%%

A short, sweet book that tells the story of a man's self discovery via the route of living his own life, not being taught. He rejects being taught in favour of learning the lessons on his own, making the mistakes himself, and coming to the conclusions through his own reasoning. 

### Some Quotes

-  "A goal stood before Siddhartha, a single goal: to become empty, empty of thirst, empty of wishing, empty of dreams, empty of joy and sorrow."
-  "Suffering was life, full of suffering was the world,"
-  "This is why I am continuing my travels—not to seek other, better teachings, for I know there are none, but to depart from all teachings and all teachers and to reach my goal by myself or to die."
-  "is not my place to judge another person’s life. Only for myself, for myself alone, I must decide, I must chose,"
-  "“It was the self, the purpose and essence of which I sought to learn. It was the self, I wanted to free myself from, which I sought to overcome."
-  "I want to learn from myself, want to be my student, want to get to know myself, the secret of Siddhartha.”"
-  "he had to start his life anew and start again at the very beginning."
-  "Now, he was nothing but Siddhartha, the awoken one, nothing else was left."
-  "When you throw a rock into the water, it will speed on the fastest course to the bottom of the water. This is how it is when Siddhartha has a goal, a resolution. Siddhartha does nothing, he waits, he thinks, he fasts, but he passes through the things of the world like a rock through water, without doing anything, without stirring; he is drawn, he lets himself fall. His goal attracts him, because he doesn’t let anything enter his soul which might oppose the goal."
-  "“Surely,” Siddhartha laughed, “surely I have travelled for my amusement. For what else? I have gotten to know people and places, I have received kindness and trust, I have found friendship."
-  "Slowly the disease of the soul, which rich people have, grabbed hold of him."
-  "He had been captured by the world, by lust, covetousness, sloth, and finally also by that vice which he had used to despise and mock the most as the most foolish one of all vices: greed."
-  "thus this sleepless man wished to free himself of these pleasures, these habits and all of this pointless life and himself,"

title: How to Avoid a Climate Disaster
author: Bill Gates
content:
%%Climate Change | Clean Energy%%

## Why Zero?
- What we need to do
	- 52 billion tons of greenhouse gas emitted each year
	- Need that to be 0
	- Cant just emit less, as that still adds to stock of gases in the atmosphere
- Hotter = Harder to live
	- Worse storms
	- More frequent storms
	- Droughts
	- Wildfires
	- Floods
	- Animals cant survive
	- Faster spread of disease
- Zero carbon can mean we produce some carbon but also remove some
- Greenhouse gases
	- Carbon Dioxide
	- Nitrous Oxide
	- Methane
- They trap heat in the atmosphere, like a greenhouse
	- Correct wavelength to let heat in
	- When reflected back, they trap heat inside the ozone layer

## Challenges
- Fossil fuels are in bloody everything
	- Plastic
	- Concrete
	- Cement
	- Steel
	- Fertiliser
	- Construction
	- Transport
- Fossil fuels are **cheap**
	- Hard to get rid of them when market gravitates toward them
- Population growth = More emissions naturally
- Outdated laws and regulations
- Need to force adoption of clean energy
	- Will be too slow otherwise
	- Global cooperation is very hard and usually too slow

## 5 Questions to Ask
1. **What percentage of the 52 billion tons are we talking about?**
2. **What is the plan for cement?**
	- Massive polluter with no clearcut solution
3. **How much power are we talking?**
4. **How much space do we need?**
	- How much power are we getting per unit of area
5. **How much will it cost?**
	- *Green Premiums* - What % excess does green solution cost

## Key areas

### Electricity (26%)
- Zero carbon electricity can decarbonise a lot of other areas by **electrification**
- Electricity is currently mostly produced by burning fossil fuels
- Green premium in the west = 15% (Higher in poor countries)
- **Storage**
	- Expensive to store electricity on a large scale (batteries too large and inefficient)
	- Makes it hard to account for the seasonality of sources like wind and solar
- Carbon free electricity
	- Nuclear fission (splitting atoms)
	- Nuclear fusion
	- Solar
	- Wind
	- Hydro
- *Big issue*: All renewable energy is **intermittent**, except for nuclear power (which is why it is so important)
- Storage in:
	- Batteries
	- Pumped hydro
	- Thermal storage
- Other solutions
	- **Carbon capture** - Will become big part of the future to offset what we cannot offset. Issue is it uses a lot of electricity in itself at the moment
	- **Using less**

### Construction (29%)
- Materials all produce carbon
	- Concrete
	- Steel
	- Plastic - Larger issue in pollution than gases
	- Glass
- **Cement issue**
	- Limestone + heat = Cement + carbon dioxide
	- Cannot prevent this, must only not use cement
- Best solutions
	- Carbon capture
	- Electrification of the material production process

### Agriculture (22%)

#### Agriculture
- Main polluters are **worse than carbon dioxide**
	- Methane from animal burps/farts
	- Nitrous oxide from animal poo
- Calorie negative
	- 1cal chicken needs 2cals to make it
	- 1cal pork needs 6cals to make it
- Best theory = Plant based meat

#### Fertiliser
- Emits twice
	1. Gas from making fertiliser
		- Made by adding heat to ammonia (heat probably from fossil fuels)
	2. Waste nitrogen from the runoff in the water

#### Deforestation
- Burning a tree causes
	- Emits all the carbon it has sucked up
	- Prevents the tree from absorbing more carbon
- 1 Americans lifetime carbon production = 50 acres of trees

### Transport (16%)
- The gold standard of **energy per dollar cost** is by far gasoline, it is amazing
- 16% globally, but this is the *biggest polluter in the united states*
- **Not passenger cars** - Aviation, shipping and trucking
- Solutions & issues
	- Electric cars
		- Cant do this with long haul trucks (massive batteries too heavy)
		- You need *35 times the size in batteries as jet fuel* for the same amount of energy
	- Biofuels
		- Alternative liquid fuels from plants etc
		- Good area to research

### Heating & Cooling (7%)

#### Cooling
- A/C units
- A larger, richer population will use more A/C (5 billion A/C units by 2050)
- To decarbonise cooling, we need to decarbonise electricity

#### Heating
- All electric heating is cheaper
- Infrastructure problem means people are still yet to transition
- Proof we need better policies to **speed up changeover**

## Adapting to a Warmer World
- Responding to what is happening now

#### Poorer Countries
- As the world gets richer, we will produce more carbon
- Need to improve the lives of the poor as the climate changes
	1. Raise the odds that malnourished children will survive
	2. Decrease the odds of children being malnourished
- **New crop varieties**
	- Resistant to floods, droughts
	- Better in different temperatures

#### Adaptation
1. Reduce the risks popsed by climate change (eg. climate-proof buildings)
2. Prepare for, and respond to emergencies (like floods and storms)
3. Plan for services for being who have been displaced (healthcare, education)

- 5 key areas to adapt
	- Early warning systems
	- Climate resistant buildings
	- Raising crop yields
	- Managing water
	- Protecting mangroves
- Geoengineering
	- Prevention, not cure
	- Last ditch efforts
	- Making temporary changes to the earths atmosphere to save us in the short term
	- **Eg putting particles in the ozone layer** to block some sunlight and cool the planet for a few weeks/months

## Plan

### Government Policy
- Spend money on R&D
- Need unity among all nations (hard)
1. Invest in R&D where the market wont do it alone
2. Tax/subsidise to correct externalities
3. Improve public information on available options
4. Keep policies up to date
5. Plan for a fair climate transition
6. Focus on hard areas of improvement too (cant just do low hanging fruit)
7. Do all three: ***technology, policy, markets***

### A Plan
1. Supply of innovation
	- Research and development
	- Take riskier bets on research
	- Focus on clean energy
2. Demand for innovation
	1. Prove it in the market (buyer of first resort?)
	2. Scale it up
- Goal to get to zero by 2050
- Federal government = Top level schemes and policies
- Local government = Bottom up buildings, houses, etc
- *Use trade to hold countries accountable for their climate actions*
- Rich countries must take the lead for poor ones

### What Each of us Can Do
- Engage in the political process
- Signal demand changes by paying up for climate friendly solutions
- Lobby for change in
	- Local government
	- Your company

# Book Two

analyse myself. Others, if they will but see, are always going

# Book Three

## On Three Kinds Of Relationships

	- "The best provision I have found for this human journey"

## On The Art Of Conversation
- "The most fruitful and natural exercise for our minds is, in my opinion, conversation"

### Who You Surround Yourself With

### Judging Character

## On Physiognomy

- "We are each of us richer than we think; but we are trained to borrow and to beg; we are taught to make more use of what is another's than of our own"
- "We need hardly any knowledge to live happily"

### Self Reliance

- "He is most powerful who has power over himself"
- "I have sufficient power over myself to keep my state of mind generally calm and free from painful brooding"

### Dont Worry
- "What good will it do you to rush ahead and welcome your misfortune, to lose the present out of fear for the future, to be miserable now because you are likely to be so in time?" - Seneca
- "He grieves more than necessary he who grieves before it is necessary"
- "A fool leads a thankless and anxious life, given over wholly to the future" - Seneca

### Good Looks
- "Nature's privelage" - Plato
- "A face is a poor guarantee, nevertheless it deserves some consideration"

## On Experience
- "When reason fails us we make use of experience"
- "Have you been able to reflect on your life and control it? Then you have performed the greatest work of all"
- "A man who knows how to enjoy his existence as he ought has attained an absolute perfection"

### Limitations Of Experience
- "Nature has pledged herself to make no second thing that is not unlike the first"
- Experience is subjective - "No two men every judged alike of the same thing"

### Laws
- "The most desirable laws are those that are fewest, simplest and most general"

- "Laws maintain their credit not because they are just, but because they are laws"
- "A man must do wrong in detail if he is to do right on the whole"

### Self Study
- "I would rather understand myself by self study than by reading Cicero"
- "It is from experience of myself that I attack human ignorance"
- Allows him to "See my own life mirrored in that of others"
- "I study everything, so from my friends' outward manifestations I discover their inward inclinations"
- Criticism
	- "One needs very strong ears to hear ones self freely criticised"
	- "Those who venture to perform this service to us show a remarkable proof of friendship"
	- Plato's requirements
		1. Knowledge
		2. Goodwill
		3. Boldness
- "Life must be studied, relished and meditated upon"

### Medicine

- "So long as I use things that I have been long accustomed to I can come to no harm"
- "I cannot think of any way in which a man can better protect himself than by quietly following the way in which he was bred and brought up"


### Breaking Rules

### Pleasure

### Suffering

title: The Selfish Gene
author: Richard Dawkins
content:
%%Refs: Biology | Evolution%%

**General idea of evolution:** There is always a cheat/outsider looking to deceive and invade a population (this is evolution basically)

## Why are People
- Individual selection > group seletion theory (The social contract - Robert Ardey)
- Inherent selfishness in genes is the predominant quality
- Altruism = Doing something at your cost & others benefit (selfish = opposite)
- How do we explain altruistic behaviour via selfish gene theory?

## The Replicators
- = A molecule with the ability to make copies of itself
- The first signs of life basically
- Errors in the copying process compound --> Change the copies
- Good replicators:
	1. Last a long time
	2. Replicate quickly
	3. Replicate accurately
- Replicators built survival machines for themselves to live in
- Nowadays the replicators are genes and we are the survival machines

## Immortal Coils
- Genes survive through multiple generations of survival machine
- Normal cell = 46 chromosomes, sex cell = 23
- Crossing over = Joining of pairs of 23 sex cells to create new cells
- Any genes aim is to maximise its survival
- Genes are roughly immortal ("immortal coils") as they could in theory last forever
- Altruism is bad for genes, selfishness is good
- This book = Gene view of evolution where genes are selfish toward their own survival
- Fun theory: The gene for dying in old age has never been removed from the gene pool as we have always reproduced by that point (in general genes survive by making reproduction occur, they dont much care what happens after)

## The Gene Machine
- This chapter all about behaviour and how genes control it
- Survival machines / how genes control them
	- Genes control indirectly (due to time lag of evolution)
	- They control behaviour, but not directly, they control lagged attributes of behaviour
- This is why learning is so important
	- Genes are very antifragile (focussed on survival and are essentially making predictions on the future using their genes)
	- Evolution of genes is analagous to reinforcement learning in complex adaptive systems
	- Ability to learn makes survival machines and genes more adaptive to the uncertain future
- Communication = One survival machine influencing the behaviour of another

## Aggression: Stability and the Selfish Machine
- Conflicts of interest
- Dawkins expects ESS theory to be biggest impact on evolution since darwin!
- Maynard Smith
	- Evolutionary Stable Strategy (ESS)
	- Gene pool finds an ESS state of stability
	- Genes find dominant strategies conditional on the current state of the gene pool - Your optimal strategy is highly dependent on the characteristics of the incumbents in a gene pool
	- Optimal strategy conditional on the environment
	- ESS is not the same as the optimum that comes form group conspiracy (this is group selection)
- Memory
	- If individuals retain memory of the past --> Altruism can be optimal

## Genesmanship
- Genes might be able to assist replicas of itself (ie. Other individuals with similar genes)
- All about helping close relatives to preserve the genes
- Animals intuitively act based on a cost-benefit analysis using relatedness for probabilities (relatedness = 1/2 for sibling, 1/4 for uncle, etc) --> Explains altruism within the family
- This calculation is **intuitive** --> Like how you dont solve differential equations when catching a ball
- Relation to yourself has the benefit of certainty (does this have some implication for idential twins?)

## Family Planning
- Individuals chase optimal birth rate to maximise the number of reared children
- Limited resources (time & food) --> Having more kids at some point becomes worse
- Bearing vs Caring tradeoff
- Genes for optimal birth rate increase from selfish action
- Group selection theory says the process is altruistic --> Individuals keep birth rates lower for the good of the group
- Selfish gene theory says it is to maximise the chance of genes succeeding

## Battle of the Generations
- Disputes among family
- The game
	- Parents have a limited resource of "parental investment" that they can distribute among the children
	- They want to maximise the genes chances in the future (relatedness of 1/2 to each child)
	- Meanwhile each individual child is interested in maximising the amount of parental investment they get themselves (relatedness of 1 to yourself)
- What emerges is a mix of the ideal situation for the child and the parent --> There is no visible optimal solution in nature

## Battle of the Sexes
- Conflict between mates/sexes
- Female exploitation
	- **Egg** = High investment, honest
	- **Sperm** = Low investment, exploitative
	- Women have all the sunk costs in the relationship, so evolution has evolved for men to exploit that
	- Same principle as the power shift that mark manson puts forward in Models where women have power before sex and men afterwards
	- Women have developed responses to the exploitation
		- Responses
			1. Domestic bliss = Look for signs of fidelity in advance (find good men)
			2. He-man
				- Go all out on good genes and risk being exploited to maximise strength of children
				- sexy husband --> Sexy kids --> More grandkids
				- "sexual selection"
- Males of a species generally more
	- Brighter and more flamboyant
	- More promiscuous
	- Less fussy in sex
- Fisher Principle = Explanation of why there are equal men and women in species generally

## You Scratch my Back, I'll Ride Yours
- Reciprocal altruism explained by selfish gene theory
- Better to be in a group and alert --> Make noise to flag incoming predator
- Symbiosis
	- Different species
	- Human symbiosis?
- Memory as a grim trigger strategy --> Explains long term altruism
- Social insect colonies
	- Divide up bearing and caring between different parties
	- Dont have equal gender ratios like most species do
	- The only species outside of man where large armies organise and fight to the death
	- Sterile worker bees --> Cannot reproduce so they maximise the chance of the colony then die

## Memes: The New Replicators
- Replicators of cultural transmission
	- Fashion
	- Religion
	- Diet
	- Art
	- Customs
	- Architecture
	- Technology
- Genetic transmission (genes) <--> Cultural transmission (memes)
- Primeordial soup --> Soup of human culture
- Non-particulate (whereas genes are particulate)
- Memes compete with each other for our brain capacity
- Genes are sort of mortal (as time tends to infinity the survival probability of all genes goes to 0)
- Memes on the other hand can last forever
- Memes can also evolve to be advantageous to itself
- Memes aim to maximise the social attention they get
- Celibacy
	- Bad for genes --> Not transmitted genetically --> Memetics instead
- "We are built as gene machines and cultured as meme machines"

## Nice Guys Finish First
- Repeated prisoners dilemma --> Nice strategy wins
	- Players cannot know when the game will end though (otherwise you get subgame perfect equilibria of defection)
- Axelrod competisions
	- Tit for tat was best strategy due to 3 qualities
		1. Nice
		2. Forgiving
		3. Non-envious
- Nice strategies cluster over a knife edge
	- The strategy clusters in groups then once over the knife edge it dominates the environment

## The Long Reach of the Gene
