- Use your own real life experiences
    - Meaning you need to go out and get some
- Don’t get too fixed on one idea
    - Avoid this by critiqing all the ideas you have
    - Must be painfully honest
    - Singlemindedness will cost you a lot of good ideas that you push away
- Disruption is good for creativity
    - Don’t be worried by a little stress/anxiety coming from all the chaos

## Absorbing Data
- Information overload leads to "information blindness"
    - We can overcome this by forcing ourselves to grapple with the data
- Disfluency
    - Make the information disfluent, so you need to work to acquire it (You can create systems to create disfluency)
    - Use the information in order to make it more memorable
    - To understand data, play around with it
- Reframing
    - In order to avoid making rash decisions, reframe the questions you're asking yourself to see what the real concequences are

title: The Art of Learning
author: Josh Waitzkin
content:
## The Foundation

### Innocent Moves
- Optimal learning comes from balancing discipline with enjoyment. This is how you improve without killing the game you are playing
- To learn optimally, you should learn for enjoyment and not for competition or ego

### Losing To Win
- Confidence is key in competition, but at the same time overconfidence is fatal
- Josh took some long breaks out at sea with his dad. He believes these breaks were instrumental in his success

### Two Approaches To Learning
- **Learning theory**: Hard work will get you to results (this is the approach you need to learn well)
- **Entity theory**: You are born inherently good or bad at things (this is perfectionism)
- Learning is a long term process, you need to take a learning theory mindset in order to keep going

### Loving The Game
- Seek out people who force you to be better
- **Process > Results** - Internalise a "process first" approach to learning
- Make your everyday feedback about effort, not about performance - This will move you toward a learning theory model and hence improve your learning
- Enjoy the game - better at coming back from losses
- **Always try your hardest** - We learn to grow our abilities by pushing them to their limits (growth comes at the point of most resistance)

### The Soft Zone
- **Hard zone**  \= Demanding a cooperative world
- **Soft zone** = At peace with the world in a fluid focus
- 3 stages of entering the soft zone:
	a. Make peace with the discomforts, allowing yourself to be focused
	b. Use the discomforts to your advantage, creating an environment of optimal performance
	c. Be able to create the advantage without the need for the discomforts
- Going through this process in different parts of your life will build mental Resilience
- Being in the soft zone means using the flow of life, not fighting it

### The Downward Spiral
- A downward spiral comes from **reacting badly to mistakes**
- To avoid this - re-enter yourself and be present
- Be conscious that **problems breed progress**
- It is easy to get angry following mistakes, it is much harder to re-centre yourself and objectively look at the mistake

### Changing Voice
- Josh took a break to Slovenia for a few months with just a backpack
- The break reignited his love for studying and learning
- He deepened his understanding and started to play chess for chess' sake again
- **"Numbers to leave numbers":** What was once seen mathematically is now felt intuitively

### Breaking Stallions
- Approach learning with a **child mindset**
  - Children do not fear failure, they approach learning from a fearless and fresh perspective
- 2 methods of breaking in a horse
  - Shock and awe - Force the student into a generic mould
  - Gentling - Work with the students strengths to let them learn in a way which is best for them

## My Second Art

### Beginner's Mind
- Looking at the learning process as though a beginner - Fresh feeling of learning opens new pathways
- He **worked hard** at tai chi from the start, putting in hours every day
- Tai chi changed his life
- The best way to learn is by finding your "natural voice" and nurturing it

### Investment In Loss
- Investing in loss = "Giving yourself to the learning process"
- Being comfortable with **losing in order to learn**
- To get to optimal performance you should **minimise repeated errors** to learn the fastest. This is what is meant by investing in loss
- Two key pillars of the learning process
	1. Beginners mind
	2. Investing in loss

### Making Smaller Circles
- **Depth > Breadth**
- He trained for hours a day at push hands
- **Master the fundamentals** - Internalise the fundamentals instead of learning a variety of skills (chess with 3 pieces)
- Making smaller circles = "**decreased extensiveness, increased potency"**
- "Numbers to leave numbers"
- Start slow and incrementally improve

### Using Adversity
- It is important to take time for the mental side of your game - Reflection is invaluable
- Using adversity = Noting how setbacks force you to higher performance, then **internalise the solution to the adversity** so you can raise your game without the setback
- He broke his hand and won the national championships 8 weeks later

### Slowing Down Time
- The **conscious mind is limited** - "numbers to leave numbers" is the solution to this. It allows us to leave the performance to the unconscious mind
- Road to mastery
	1. Fundamentals - Solid understanding of these, drilled relentlessly
	2. Expand repetoire - Guided by your perception
	3. Keep in touch with what you feel to be core to the discipline
- **Chunking** is a method of grouping large sets of data together for your unconscious to make links and perform in a way that the conscious mind could not

### The Illusion Of The Mystical
- **"At the opponents slightest move, I move first"** - Subtly control the intentions of your opponent
- **Balance** is key in virtually every sport
- Programme your opponent unconsciously
- At the top level of any sport, the battles are all psychological

## Bringing It All Together

### The Power Of Presence
- You should always be present
- Being present should be like breathing
- When learning you must **maintain a present focus** and not just go through the motions
- **Practise mindfully to compete mindfully**

### Searching For The Zone
- By forcing yourself to focus, you get better at focusing
- **Practise focus and recovery**
- The ability to relax and recover quickly is common to all top performers
- Better at recovering means you will perform better under stress
- Cardio interval training improves mental energy
- **Apply the stress and recovery process** to all aspects of your life

### Building Your Trigger
- Build a routine that plays off what makes you feel most alert
- Enjoy waiting - Your life is only ever the present moment so live it
- **Make being present a habit** - Meditation is good for this
- Take your trigger routine - Internalise it - Incrementally shorten it - Make it flexible

### Making Sandals
- "To walk a thorny road, we may cover its every inch with leather or we can make sandals"
- If you can learn to control yourself then you can control any situation, instead of learning to control each situation individually
- 3 steps of performance:
	1. Learn to flow with distraction
	2. Learn to use the distraction, inspiring ourselves
	3. Learn to recreate the inspiring settings internally
- Become comfortable with all emotions - Channelling them to improve performance
- **Train in adverse conditions** to make sure your sandals can make it over the road
- Using your environment as toughening stimulation
	- **Use emotions as fuel**
	- Get comfortable with your emotions to increase your resilience

### Bringing It All Together
- Adjust the lessons in this book to your own personal disposition
- **Know and use your unique strength** to win
- Page 225 is a great summary of the whole book

### Taiwan
- Good foundations in a field make you flexible to changes
- Stay present to not get rattled

title: Lessons of History
author: Will & Ariel Durant
content:
Will and Ariel Durant wrote a beastly eleven-volume set of books called 'The Story of Civilization'. This book is a much more approachable summary of what the themes they found across those eleven books. I like it more than most history books I've read because it discusses themes and principles more than specific events. If you're looking to learn from history books then (as the name suggests), this one will give you some good education. Straight from the pen of those who have spent their lives studying it.

### 1. Hesitations
- The present is the past rolled up for action, while the past is the present unrolled for understanding
 
### 2. History And The Earth
- Historically, geography has played a significant part in history as countries with more coastline had more trade routes
- As technology improves, geography is becoming less important
 
### 3. Biology And History
- Three lessons of history with regards to biological life
1.	Life is a competition
  - Nowadays we just compete in groups (race, religion, football team, country)
2.	Life is selection
  - Inequality is very natural
  - Below average - Want equality
  - Above average - Want freedom
  - So therefore there is freedom as the above average are the ones with control
3.	Life must breed
  - Nature has a passion for quantity
 
### 4. Race And History
- Historically, the purer races have had more success
  - Eg Aryans and Nordics
- Growth of the non-nordics --> History is colour blind
- Civilizations create races, not the other way around
 
### 5. Character And History
- Human nature = The fundamental tendencies of mankind
- The character of mankind has not changed throughout history much
- Innovative "men of action" lead the way for the imitators (everyone else)
 
### 6. Morals And History
- Morality - Rules which compel society's members to behave in a way that is consistent with order, security and growth
- 3 stages of history
	1.	Hunting
	2.	Agriculture
	3.	Industry
- Morals change throughout history
- The morals of the industrial age are unclear at the moment
 
### 7. Religion And History
- "As long as there is poverty there will be gods" - Religion gives meaning to the poor
- Historically, the church would hold all people responsible for their actions
  - This enforces a moral code as everyone is accountable to the church
- Industrial revolution: Religion --> Secularism
- The story of religion = religion (morals) vs state (laws)
  - Religion used to be winning but it has not been since the industrial revolution
 
### 8. Economics And History
- Marx: "History is economics in action"
- At the end of the day all men are driven by a profit motive
- A natural inequality of ability leads to a natural inequality of wealth
  - This wealth is then redistributed by law following a revolution
- The concentration of wealth is periodically redistributed by violent revolt
 
### 9. Socialism And History
- Socialism only seems to be preferable during war time
- It inevitably leads to dictatorship and serfdom (Try to leave --> Forced to stay)
- Socialism has failed many times in history, from Peru to China
- Industrial revolution resurrected communism through Marx and Hegel ("Communist manifesto")
- In recent years it appears that capitalist economies are embracing socialism and vice versa
  - The world appears to be slowly moving toward a system somewhere in the middle
 
### 10. Government And History
- Government controls the limits to freedom
  - The aim of government is to maximise freedom while establishing order
- Nerva to Marcus Aurelius is regarded as the greatest ruling period
- Historically, monarchy has proved better at ruling than democracy
- States are very complex. Therefore oligarchy tends to perform better than monarchy as it is impossible for a single person to hold all that information in their head
- "Does history justify revolutions?"
- As things get more complex, inequality will get worse as those who understand will become more powerful and fewer in number
- Democracy = The right to opportunity, not the right to power
 
### 11. History And War
- Individuals are restrained by morals and law, but states and countries are not. Hence there is war
- Until 20th century war was always between aristocracies, then the people were brought into it
 
### 12. Growth And Decay
- There is no certainty that history will repeat the past, but there is some sort of life cycle
- Civilizations do not have a life expectancy and they can live forever, the reason they don't is because something kills them
- Civilizations are still driven by men of "clear mind and energetic will"
 
### 13. Is Progress Real?
- Science is a neutral existence, as it can both build and destroy
- 3 measures of progress (and if we have progressed)
  - Happiness (we are arguably less happy today than in hunter gatherer times)
  - Control of environment (we certainly have more control of the world today)
  - Education (we are more educated today both at the expert level and the baseline minimum childhood education)
- Progress in heritage - We will always have a richer history than ever before as long as time keeps going forward

title: Sapiens
author: Yuval Noah Harari
content:
Sapiens breaks the history of humanity down into 3 revolutions, which is how the book is set up. For each revolution, I've summarised the section, then saved some clippings from the book itself. 

> "Luxuries tend to become necessities and spawn new obligations"

## The Cognitive Revolution (70,000 Years Ago)

### Summary
- Homo sapiens began to flood the planet, dominating large chunks of the globe
- Harari says that they did this thanks to 1 advantage specifically - **language**
  - The difference between animal language and human language is that humans can use language to talk about things that are not real
  - This allows them to create imaginary situations, orders and rituals which bond tribes together and point large groups toward a common goal (religion, politics, money etc)
- In the process of becoming smarter and more adept than other species, homo sapiens committed some of the greatest mass murders in history, and as a group we have wiped out more species than any other

### Notes From Book
- At the beginning of existence, there were many species of human - Homo erectus, homo sapiens, etc
  - Homo sapiens originated in east Africa
  - We became the smartest type of sapiens and hence took over during the cognitive revolution
- The common myths that out language permitted is made us so good at operating in large groups
- One-on-one, a human stood no chance against a neanderthal, but in large groups the neanderthals would lose battles badly
- Dogs were the first domesticated animal, roughly 15,000 years ago

## The Agricultural Revolution (12,000 Years Ago)

### Summary
- Humans stopped foraging about 12,000 years ago and began to settle down into farms. The transition from going to get the food, to bringing the food to us
- In theory, farming gave us a better life, but Harari disputes this. He says that farming was the biggest fraud in history
  - Longer working hours
  - Easier spread of disease
  - Worse nutrition from eating the same thing repetetively
- He argues that the farms actually domesticated us, having us work harder to help wheat reproduce faster was arguably the success of the wheat, not us
- Farms were also the birthplace of a new set of imagined realities - Kingdoms, nobility and gods
- These new myths lead to mass opression of the poor (or simply the creation of the lower class)
- In the agricultural revolution we also developed and perfected the use of numbers and writing for purposes such as tax, laws and accounting (in a very simplified way)

### Notes From Book
- The essence of the agricultural revolution = "The ability to keep more people alive under worse conditions"
- Extra food translated into population explosion and pampered elites, not better lifestyles
- But this was a trap - If population grows from 100 to 110, which 10 people will volunteer to die of starvation to go back to the better days with higher quality of life?
- "Luxuries tend to become necessities and spawn new obligations"
- This whole period showed the stark difference between evolutionary success and individual happiness, the population was booming from a growth perspective but everyone but the elite were in poverty
- We are in an age of romantic consumerism - Romantic = We must have as many different experiences as possible. Consumerist = We must consume as many products as possible
- On accounting and record keeping:
  - The most important impact of script on human history is precisely this: it has gradually changed the way humans think and view the world. Free association and holistic thought have given way to compartmentalisation and bureaucracy
- Many of those that signed the declaration of independence had slaves, as they considered the declaration to not apply to negroes
- How the bible looks at marriage and rape: ‘If a man meets a virgin who is not betrothed, and seizes her and lies with her, and they are found, then the man who lay with her shall give to the father of the young woman fifty shekels of silver, and she shall be his wife’
- Money is the most useful system of mutual trust ever devised
- "Christians slaughtered Christians by the millions to defend slightly different interpretations of the religion of love and compassion"
- Harari's theory of religion - "So, monotheism explains order, but is mystified by evil. Dualism explains evil, but is puzzled by order. There is one logical way of solving the riddle: to argue that there is a single omnipotent God who created the entire universe – and He’s evil. But nobody in history has had the stomach for such a belief"
- The idea of buddhism is that craving is the enemy - we crave bad things to go away, and we crave good things to stay
- Nirvana - "When the flames are completely extinguished, craving is replaced by a state of perfect contentment and serenity, known as nirvana (the literal meaning of which is ‘extinguishing the fire’)."


## The Scientific Revolution (500 Years Ago)

### Summary
- Since the cognitive revolution, humans have tried to understand the universe
- The main change in the scientific revolution is the acceptance that we don't know everything. This set the stage for testing hypotheses and humble research involving open minds
- Also, the use of mathematics and physical laws were devevloped significantly in this stage
- We are still in this stage
- Lightning was believed to be god's wrath until Ben Franklin proved it wasn’t by inventing lightning rods
- The driver of modern science is credit - Those with the money to fund research will ultimately succeed faster/greater than those who put less money into these discoveries
- Scientists are controlling the minds of animals, they are extending the lives of people and curing them of illnesses
  - Science is doing what religious people used to put down to god
- Science is doing gods work
- Anything is natural if it can occur - Nobody ever stops to make sure people are not photosynthesising because it cannot happen, but extending the life of a person through scientific research has occurred and hence is natural

### Notes From Book
- The founders of scottish windows, Webster and Wallace first applied statistics to the death of priests
- Scientists usually assume that no theory is 100 per cent correct. Consequently, truth is a poor test for knowledge. The real test is utility. A theory that enables us to do new things constitutes knowledge.
- _"The Royal Society of London for the Improvement of Natural Knowledge concluded that this was not enough. To obtain the most accurate results it was imperative to send an astronomer all the way to the south-western Pacific Ocean. The Royal Society resolved to send an eminent astronomer, Charles Green, to Tahiti, and spared neither effort nor money. But, since it was funding such an expensive expedition, it hardly made sense to use it to make just a single astronomical observation. Green was therefore accompanied by a team of eight other scientists from several disciplines, headed by botanists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander. The team also included artists assigned to produce drawings of the new lands, plants, animals and peoples that the scientists would no doubt encounter. Equipped with the most advanced scientific instruments that Banks and the Royal Society could buy, the expedition was placed under the command of Captain James Cook, an experienced seaman as well as an accomplished geographer and ethnographer"_ - James cook lead the expedition of experiments which calculated the suns distance from the earth
-  Amerigo Vespucci argued for the existence of America, whereas most people throught it was the east coast of Asia. So a famous mapmaker drew a map and called this "new continent" America, after him. - This is how america got its name
- Wall Street  \- the Dutch West Indies Company, or WIC, plied the Atlantic. In order to control trade on the important Hudson River, WIC built a settlement called New Amsterdam on an island at the river’s mouth. The colony was threatened by Indians and repeatedly attacked by the British, who eventually captured it in 1664. The British changed its name to New York. The remains of the wall built by WIC to defend its colony against Indians and British are today paved over by the world’s most famous street – Wall Street"
- The industrial schedule - "An alarm clock wakes us up at 7 a.m., we heat our frozen bagel for exactly fifty seconds in the microwave, brush our teeth for three minutes until the electric toothbrush beeps, catch the 07:40 train to work, run on the treadmill at the gym until the beeper announces that half an hour is over, sit down in front of the TV at 7 p.m. to watch our favourite show, get interrupted at preordained moments by commercials that cost $1,000 per second, and eventually unload all our angst on a therapist who restricts our prattle to the now standard fifty-minute therapy hour"

title: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century
author: Yuval Noah Harari
content:
Yuval Noah Harari

Key Themes
- AI and technology will create a class of humans which suffer from irrelevance, adding no value to the world
- There is a big difference between believing my country is unique, and it is supreme
- The future requires adaptability, not technical skills. We need to be learing how to be flexible and resiliant, not how to operate specific pieces of machinery
- Nationalism = My nation is unique, Fascism = My nation is supreme
 
## 1. Disillusionment	
- Humans think in stories. In the 20th century the main ones were:
  - Fascism - Eliminated in world war 2
  - Communism - Eliminated in the post world war 2 period (cold war)
  - Liberalism - lives on as the winner in most societies
- Harari argues that now, in 2018, we are down to 0 working stories (Liberalism is failing)
- AI has already augmented us
- Populist revolts may not work when the thing you are protesting is irrelevance
 
## 2. Work
- Technology will eventually be able to detect human emotions by using biomechanics, which will mean that it can begin to replace more relationship based jobs like Bankers and Nurses
- The job market in 2050 will be very different to today thanks to AI, jobs will be destroyed but will also be created
- Universal basic income (capitalist paridise) vs Universal basic services (Communist paridise)
- Wealth inequality is likely to increase as the jobs that used to be done by indian children are now done by a 3d printer, funding tech giants instead of poor families
 
## 3. Liberty
- Voting is not about what you think, it is about what you feel
- Self driving cars don’t need to be perfect, they just need to be better than humans (not hard)
- Big data is watching you
- The invention of the biometric sensor is a big one as it turns human feelings into data that a computer can process
- Will we lose the free will to choose things as computers become so tuned in to what we want that we no longer need to choose? Is this a good thing?
- Once humans begin to trust the algorithms, we will stop knowing what they are doing and will no longer be able to explain what it is doing
 
## 4. Equality
- The new currency of this century is data
- Those who own the data own the future
- Key question: How do you regulate the ownership of data?
- If you cannot see the data that is coming from an interaction, you are the data
- The richest 1% may eventually be able to buy better bodies and brains, so not only are they richer than you, they can not afford to be bigger and smarter than you too
 
## 5. Community
- Humans are being detatched from their bodies by tehnology
- Physical communities are being broken up by technology
- It is easier than ever to talk to someone on the other side of the world but harder than ever to do so in person because they are always on their phone
 
## 6. Civilisation
- Small civilisations have been merging into larger and larger ones thanks to technology
- "We are all cogs within a single global production line"
- Globalisation --> A single large civilisation
- We have lost the little civilisations that used to exist
 
## 7. Nationalism
- There is nothing wrong with being patriotic, but there is definitely something wrong with being excessively nationalistic.
- There is a big difference between believing my country is unique, and it is supreme
- The environment
  - The water footprint of eating meat is huge
  - Technology is providing us with substitutes to meat, by growing it in a lab
- 3 threats facing humanity:
  - Technology
  - Nuclear
  - Ecological
- We have a global economy and national politics, this mismatch must change for the world to work
 
## 8. Religion
- Marx was very against religion, saying it has nothing to add to political debate
- We need to distinguish between 3 types of problem:
1.	Technical problems - How farmers deal with dead crops
2.	Policy problems - What measures should governments adopt to stop global warming
3.	Identity problems - Why should someone care about the problems of this farmer
 
## 9. Immigration
- Definition
1.	Host country allows immigrants into the country
2.	In return, immigrants embrace the norms and values of the country
3.	After sufficient time the country accepts the immigrant as a full member of the country
- He says you cant be too tolerant, if you allow too many people from the middle east into your country you start to look like the middle east and lose your national identity
 
## 10. Terrorism
- It is like a fly in a china shop, the only way it can cause damage is by getting into the ear of the bull
- Terrorism annoys angers countries into overreaction
 
## 11. War
- There is less war now are the valuable commodity is data
- You cannot go to silicon valley and steal the silicon in the same way you could go to india and steal the gold
- The main commodity is knowledge, so there will not be physical wars to get knowledge, but more likely technological ones
 
## 12. Humility
- You are not the centre of the world
- Apes and humans developed the tendency to help the poor and needy long before the bible came about
- Crediting christianity with the concept of generosity is like crediting the jews with the theory of relativity
 
## 13.14: God/Secularism
- Harari says morality has nothing to do with god, you just need to understand suffering to have a firm grasp on being a moral person
- Secularism promotes truth above all things
- Belief usually is required when something is not true
- This commitment to truth via secularism has spurred modern science
- Religion often claims to be perfect, but you always trust somebody more who is open with their flaws than someone who says they have none
 
## 15. Ignorance
- Accepting ignorance is key
- Nobody knows everything
- On free will: We don’t even know about our own behavioural biases most of the time, we are largely ignorant of this
- We rely on experts for an ever increasing amount of information
- We treat the knowledge in the minds of others as if it were our own, so we thing we know a lot when we don’t
- As a result, we should be investing time into fact checking an
- You need to experiment with unproductive paths to fully understand a topic, which requires a lot of time
 
## 17. Post-Truth
- Football clubs bring out something inside of us which ensures we take a side
- Harari says that the nations and religions are like football clubs on steroids
- It is the responsibility of all of us to verify the sources of information that we use, which we can do in a number of ways:
  - If you want good information, pay good money for it - Brainwashing information (like facebook) is free, good quality information (like some academic journals) is not free
  - If an issue is important to you, make the effort to read the scientific literature on the subject
 
## 18. Science Fiction
- Far more people watch TV shows like black mirror and movies like the matrix and terminator
- So science fiction producers need to be more responsible with what they are putting out, as it has more impact on the collective view of technology than academic research does
- In thinking about the future, Karl Marx is still a better guide than Steven Spielberg
 
## 19. Education
- The change in required learning
  - The information that children learn at the moment is not going to be useful in 2050 when they actually get around to applying it
  - What they really need to be teaching in schools is "learning how to learn" and adaptability
  - Need to move from learning hard technical skills to softer and more general life skills
- Getting used to changing and unfamiliar situations
- Preserving mental balance in these situations
- Information overflow
  - We are bombarded with too much information on everything, the last thing a teacher needs to do is give the pupils more information than they already have
- Adults like stability a bit too much, which makes them more vulnerable to the future than the 15 year olds, so Harari's advice is not to take on board too much of what the adults say, stay childish and flexible
- Stories
  - If you want someone to believe a story, induce them to make a sacrifice on its behalf.
- Giving diamond rings to lovers
- Spending 30 years reading the scriptures of a religion
  - After the sacrifice, the sunk cost bias will do the rest and they will force themselves to believe the story
- Teachings of budda
  - Everything is constantly changing
  - Nothing has any enduring essence
  - Nothing is completely satisfied
 
## 20. Meaning
- The universe does not give any meaning to your life, you do that yourself
- Don’t try to fit yourself into a ready made plan
- Humans have the freedom to do what we desire, but not to choose what we desire
 
## 21. Meditation
- The deepest source of suffering is our own minds
- Suffering is something that our minds experience, not something that is objectively happening in the outside world
- Meditation is about how you get in touch with reality
- Harari sees meditation as a scientific tool which can be used to view conciousness

title: 7 Brief Lessons on Physics
author: Carlo Rovelli
content:
### Most beautiful Theory
- Einstein discovered that the gravitational field IS the space Newton talked about
- Cosmic background radiation from the big bang (explosion of a small overheated universe that made our large ever expanding one) is proof of the big bang
 
### Quanta
- The idea of light as photons (packets of energy)
- Werner Heisenberg devised the idea that electrons only exist when being interacted with, and that when not so, they are simply a calculable probability, this helped with the quantum leap theory/idea
- Quantum mechanics is using the idea that no object has a definite position unless colliding with something else
- To this day we cannot prove why this theory holds, we just accept it
 
### Architecture of the Cosmos
- Corpernicus proved the earth wasn't the centre of everything 
- The universe began as a small ball and exploded into its current cosmic dimensions
- There are billions of planets out there just like Earth, as our galaxy is one of billions
- A grain of sand on a beach has more significance than our galaxy in the universe
 
### Particles
- Quarks are glued together by gluons to make protons and neutrons
- Electrons quarks photons and gluons are the elementary particles that make up everything around us, they fluctuate between existence and non existence according to quantum theory
- "Standard model of elementary particles"
- There is a large cloud of dark matter surrounding every galaxy
- Dark matter is just something we know is there but don't know what it is, and the standard model doesn't explain it
 
### Loop Quantum Gravity Theory
- Quantum mechanics and general relativity conflict each other but are both such good theories 
- Loop quantum gravity theory says that space is made up of minute particles (atoms of space) that link together to give the texture of space
- The atoms of space are not in space because they are space
- This theory does not include time, everything moves on its own time scale and there is no universal passing of time
- A black hole is a rebounding Planck star that is expanding in extreme slow motion, if you were on the star of would seem fast as the lack of gravity speeds up time
- This theory says that the big bang was actually a bounce outward following a previous universe collapsing in on itself like a black hole for universes
 
### Probability, Time and The Heat of Black Holes
- Heat is atoms vibrating more quickly 
- Heat proves that time exists, without friction (heat transfer) a pendulum would fluctuate forever and if you played it in reverse would seem the same, but with friction you can tell the future (small fluctuations) from the past (larger fluctuations)
- Boltzmann discovered that heat moves from hot to cold due to probability. It is much more likely a fast vibrating particle hits a still one than vise versa, and due to the conservation of energy it gives energy to the still one
- We don't know how gravitational field are affected by heat. How does space-time change with heat? It must vibrate but what does vibrating time look like
- We do not say that things not 'here' don't exist so why do we say things not 'now' don't exist? This confuses physicists
- Hawking proved black holes are always hot using quantum mechanics
- His theory combines all 3 main physics approaches, quantum mechanics, general relativity and thermodynamics
 
### Ourselves 
- "Integrated information theory" - theory about the structure of a system that makes it concious. What changes when we sleep etc
- To be free means to make decisions based on what's going on in your mind. Not externally 
- "Homo" species are characterised by being curious (humans, chimps, Neanderthals)

title: Homo Deus
author: Yuval Noah Harari
content:
## Part 0: The New Human Agenda

This book is a history of the future, it uses the past 300 years to predict how humans will develop into god's in the future (it may turn out different)

### New Human Agenda
- We aim to attain divinity (not omnipotence!) Sort of like the Greek gods
- Peace is not a default, not war
- War is no longer profitable as we have moved from material economies to information economies

### A-Mortality
- Not immortality (=god)
- Lead to less risk taking - why risk infinity?

### Human Rights
- Right to pursuit of happiness
- Right to liberty
- Right to life

### Pursuit Of Happiness
- We use drugs to emulate chemical feelings we can get naturally, but for less effort
- The harder we try to achieve happiness the more miserable we may become

### Enhancing Humanity
- The same tech that can replace a severed leg can improve a perfectly normal one
- Idea that we can extrapolate bringing people back to the norm through to improving the norm
- Plastic surgery started off saving war veterans and now is focused on footballers

### Learning From History
- Gardens began as signs of wealth, as the poor couldn't afford to waste the land (untameable proof of your richness)
- What we learn from history is not to repeat it, but to do it differently and see how things change

## Part 1: Homo Sapiens Conquers The World
- Evolution from thousands of years ago has shaped animals into something humans are forcing them not to be (pigs want to roam but are battery processed in cages)

### Algorithms
- \= methodical set of steps that can be used to make calculations, resolve problems and reach decisions
	- EG calculating the average or the recipe for a meal

### Theory Of Evolution
- Natural selection says that parts of us are iterated toward improvement over generations
- Being individual means we cannot be divided, so cannot be iterated and so contradicts natural selection (we have no souls)

### The Mind
- The mind subjectively reacts to neurones but the traffic jam doesn't subjectively react to the cars
- The mind (consciousness) is us feeling
- The best theory of the mind/consciousness is that it is mental pollution - a biproduct of billions of firing neurones (much like the noise of a jet plane engines, in reality serving no purpose)
- If the mind can be replicated by electoral impulses then it could be year 2250 and you're in a simulation, given there could be infinite simulations (close enough given billions of neurones) the probability youre in the real world is roughly 0

### Cooperation
- Homo sapiens dominate the world not because of our intelligence but because of our ability to communicate and cooperate in large numbers flexibly
- If cooperation is all that separates sapiens from animals then should we at all be reverted to be special? Do we have souls?
- Ultimatum game - one player splits $100 and the other decides to accept the split or make nobody get anything (should be equilibrium at 99-1 but really at 60-40)

### Web Of Meaning
- Humans only believe in objective reality (like gravity) and subjective reality (like an unexplainable headache)
- There is actually also intersubjective reality which is reality created by the belief of masses (like the value of a dollar bill/beleif in God) - creates a web of meaning (it has value because all your friends also believe it does, and they believe because you do)

## Part 2: Homo Sapiens Gives Meaning To The World

### Invention Of Writing
- Enables more complex stories and algorithms to be recorded (doesnt matter who the doctor is he's following a WRITTEN code of practice)

### Failures Of Writing
- Mao of China ordered increases in agriculture that were unobtainable. So those recording grain production lied, this was amplified all the way up the chain of command until it said that production was 50% more that it really was. China then bought lots of weapons in return for their grain and experienced an aweful famine

### Divorce And Monotheists
- The same way small kids are childish in thinking the divorce is due to them, monotheists are childiah for thinking droughts are because of their sins
- The irony of putting your hand on a Bible and swearing to tell the truth is comedic given the book is filled with fiction

### Stories
- They are tools without which humanity cannot function
- They should not be seen as real (this is what religion does)

### Science And Religion
- Religion = any all encompassing story that confers superhuman legitimacy onto human laws, this explaining everything through an external force
- Science requires religion to give us values to live by, science just explains the laws of the world. Someone must create rules/values.
	- Three gorges damn economic Vs ethical issues
- Sam Harris argues that all ethical arguments conceal some facts, and so science can prove/disprove ethical statements

### The Modern Covenant
- The deal says - humans agree to give up on meaning in exchange for power
- Humans are not confined to any predetermined role in the modern world so they do as they please because 'shit happens'

### The Modern Pursuit Of Power
- Growth is key, confidence in growth is displayed through provision of credit which fuels business financing and therefore future growth
- Significant global figures take more risks today because they assumed scientific discovery will save things even if they're wrong (Eg air cleaning domes in Beijing instead of less pollution) 

### The Humanist Revolution
- Humanism is like replacing god with yourself/humanity
- If it feels good and doesnt make anyone else feel bad - do it
- Humanist equation: knowledge = experience \* sensitivity
- An experience = sensations, emotions, thoughts
- You only respect the outcome of a vote if you believe you share experiences and thoughts with everyone else that voted. Otherwise you'll think it doesn't count because they don't understand
- Liberal humanism - each human is special and should do as they please (you're free to starve) - capitalistic properties
- Socialist humanism - humans are special but should do what is best for ALL humans
- Evolutionary humanism - survival of the fittest, what doesn't kill you improves you and you should extinct the weak (Nazis are an extreme version)
- Socialism (Marx, Lenin) went along with production and hence progressed through the industrial revolution whereas Buddhism/other religions didn't
- Now liberalism is doing to socialism what socialism did you Buddhism. The information age is dominated by liberalism

## Part 3: Homo Sapiens Loses Control

### The Time Bomb Of The Laboratory
- Science has discovered that humans are made up of genes, neurones etc. And their mutations can be random. So humans are not at all free --> this skrews liberalism (think of the uranium robot picking right or left)
- Through probabilities and random determination science has proved freedom doesn't really exist
- Theory of evolution backs this up
- Humans are free to act upon their desires, but they aren't free to choose them
- Robot rats show how if there is no free will, then humans are 100% controllable

### Who Is I?
- Liberalism centres on your true self choosing as it pleases - but is there only 1 self?
- Kahneman proved there is a narrating self and a experiencing self with his "long" and "short" cold water experiment - peak end rule doesn't aggregate, it averages. (Narrating self is the inner voice)

### The Great Decoupling Of Intelligence And Conciousness
- For now, in armies and corporations Intelligence is mandatory, conciousness is optional
- This paves the way for computers
- After winning jeaproady IBM's Watson has been focusing on medical diagnosis
- Computers always break barriers we don't think they could - We used to think recognising faces was inherently human
- VITAL is an algorithm given a chair on the management of a large Chinese company - it can vote and usually does so in favour of giving more power to algorithms
- Page 378 - humans can compose algorithms
- It's clear that computers will take a lot of human jobs. So the key is to make NEW jobs that humans do better than algorithms
- "Self Knowledge through numbers" - giving all your biometric data to an algorithm that will tell you all about yourself
- 23andme can help you "know thyself" for $99
- Liberalism will collapse the day computer algorithms know us better than we know ourselves. As at that point every decision is better off being made by the algorithm
- A study done by Facebook found that on average 300 likes is all it needs to predict your result of a personality test better than your spouse (70 for friends)
- Scary part is we will be better for it

### 3 Potential Futures

1. Humans lose their value completely
2. Humans are still valuable as a collective, to perform tasks that only a human can do, but the individual in each of us has no value
3. There are a select few specialists that retain individual value and they will constitute an elite of upgraded humans

### 3 Upgrading Inequality
- Liberalism still assumes the value of the poor is equal to the rich (1 vote each) - will this stay even when there are biological differences?
- If this superhuman elite develop, liberalism will collapse as not all humans can be valued equally

### Techno Humanism
- Homo sapiens has run its course, but through technology it can become homo Deus and continue to make history
- Techno - humanism assumes we know and understand the mind fully. We really don't, we only scratch the surface of the spectrum of consciousness
- Humanity never fully pays attention to things because of the FOMOA - Fear of Missing Out
- If we gained the technological ability to control human desire, humans become another designer product

### The Data Religion
- Everything can be explained through data flows
- Data algorithms give a common language to all sciences
- The biggest breakthrough is the discovery that organisms are still just complex algorithms
- Distributed data processing (like a stock exchange where the fee market decides prices) is superior to centralised data processing (like communist Russia)
- World leaders lack the vision to do anything with the powerful technology available - Hollywood villains and Hitler were at least people with vision
- Dataism believes humans are merely tools to create the "internet of all things"

title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
author: Dale Carnegie
content:
## Fundamental Techniques In Handling People

1. **Don't criticize, condemn or complain**
  - Any fool can complain, it takes character and self control to be understanding and forgiving

2. **Give honest and sincere appreciation**
  - There is only one way to get someone to do something, and that is by making them want to do it
  - People crave to be appreciated

3. **Arouse in the other person an eager want**
  - In order to influence people you must talk about what they want and show them how to get it
  - Before you speak, look at things from the other persons perspective and consider what they want

## Six Ways To Make People Like You

1. **Become genuinely interested in other people**
  - They have a lot to offer and it is arrogant not to listen to them
  - Don't try to make people interested in you!
  - We are interested in others when they are interested in us
  - Greet people with genuine enthusiasm

2. **Smile**
  - People succeed at things they have fun doing
  - So do what you love, then tell your face!
  - Actions speak louder than words

3. **Remember that a person's name is to that person the sweetest and most important sound in any language**
  - Remember and use people's names
  - Saying someone's name is like a subconscious complement to them
  - Try to associate their name with their features
  - Ask them how to spell it

4. **Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves**
  - Listen because you are genuinely interested (and you should be)
  - Give the person speaking your exclusive, undivided attention
  - Ask questions that they will enjoy answering

5. **Talk in terms of the other persons interests**
  - Theodore Roosevelt stayed up the night before a dinner reading about topics that his guests were interested in
  - Put effort into knowing about what they like to talk about

6. **Make the other person feel important, and do so sincerely**
  - The feeling of importance is one of the fundamental human desires
  - Everyone feels themselves superior to you in some way, you can get to their hearts by recognizing and highlighting it
  -  "Talk to people about themselves and they will listen for hours"

## How To Win People To Your Way Of Thinking

1. **The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it**
  - Recognise that this argument is an opportunity for you to learn
  - Listen to the other person first
  - Look for areas of agreement
  - Remember: Anyone that puts in the effort to argue with you is interested in the same things you are

2. **Show respect for the other person's opinions. Never say "you're wrong"**
  - You will never get into trouble for admitting that you might be wrong
  - Be diplomatic in argument
  - Highlight the knowledge of the other person

3. **If you are wrong, admit it quickly and emphatically**
  - When we are right, we must try to win people gently and tactfully. When we are wrong we must admit our mistakes quickly and with enthusiasm
  - Say about yourself all the bad things the other person will say, and say them before they do
  - Any fool can defend a mistake, it takes character to admit it was just an error

4. **Begin in a friendly way**
  - "A drop of honey catches more flies than a gallon of gall"
  - Kindliness and a friendly approach can make people change their minds more easily than by forcing them

5. **Get the other person saying "yes, yes" immediately**
  - Socratic method - Get them to agree with statements then show how their argument disagrees with themselves
  - Keep emphasising the things on which you agree
  - Ask gentle questions that the other person will say yes to

6. **Let the other person do a great deal of talking**
  - People won't pay attention to you while they still have a lot they want to say, they will be waiting to speak
  - This is best used when handling complaints

7. **Let the other person feel like the idea is his or hers**
  - We much prefer to feel that we are making decisions on our own accord
  - Ask them what they want, then provide it for them. This way you have enabled their own idea

8. **Try honestly to see things from the other persons point of view**
  - Put yourself in their place
  - Govern what you will say by what you would want to hear if you were the listener
  - Think in terms of the other persons point of view

9. **Be sympathetic with the other person's ideas and desires**
  - Most people you meet are thirsty for sympathy - "I don't blame you"
  - Don't just go blaming them, especially if they have made a mistake

10. **Appeal to the nobler motives**
  - People like to think they are following motives that sound good
  - Make them feel that you regard them as honest, noble and fair

11. **Dramatize your ideas**
  - Merely stating a truth is not enough, the truth must be made vivid
  - TV is dramatic and everyone loves it
  - Showmanship makes a difference

12. **When nothing else works, throw down a challenge**
  - Stimulate competition
  - People desire a feeling of importance. Competition and challenge provides this opportunity

## Be A Leader: How To Change People Without Giving Offence Or Arousing Resentment

1. **Begin with praise and honest appreciation**
  - If you have to find fault, give a sincere complement first
  - Make them feel important
  - Then sympathise with them

2. **Call attention to people's mistakes indirectly**
  - Change the word "but" to "and"
  - "I'm proud your grades have got better, and if you keep it up your algebra will get better too"

3. **Talk about your own mistakes before criticising the other person**
  - People want to feel superior, by highlighting your own mistakes they can still feel so
  - They will also identify with you more and hence you could make a friend

4. **Ask questions instead of giving direct orders**
  - This gives people the opportunity to choose to do things themselves
  - You will save their pride and keep them feeling important
  - This also gives them more room to be creative

5. **Let the other person save face**
  - What matters is what people think of themselves, so make it good
  - Allow them to stay feeling important

6. **Praise the slightest improvement. Be "hearty in your approbation and lavish in your praise"**
  - Be specific in your praise for it to be more sincere
  - You must genuinely believe it though
  - People improve when you encourage them and get worse when you condemn them

7. **Give the other person a fine reputation to live up to**
  - People will feel important provided that they live up to their reputation
  - Give a dog a good name

8. **Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct**
  - You want to incentivise them to improve
  - Let them know you have faith in their ability
  - Let them know that they have an undeveloped flair for their work

9. **Make the other person happy about doing things you suggest**
  - Point out the benefits to them of doing what you suggest
  - Give others authority

title: Buyology
author: Martin Lindstrom
content:
%%Psychology%%

Some say using neuroscience for marketing purposes will take things too far, like engineering addiction. But that's like using a hammer to kill someone, when used correctly neuromarketing is incredibly useful

## 1. The Largest Neuromarketing Study Ever Conducted
- Used a functional MRI machine (fMRI) to measure brain activity of smokers during 4 hours of not smoking
- China contributes to 1/3 of all smoking in the world
- In the scanner the smokers were shown the adverts that go on cigarette packets, and they had no effect on making smokers want to smoke less, just stimulated a craving area in the brain.
- The interesting part is that in a questionnaire beforehand, all the smokers said that the ads did affect them
- Focus groups and surveys don't account for the little things we unconsciously react to such as the surveyor is a feminist so we don't like the product
- By looking at the brain we get past all these micro-emotions, an fMRI or SST machine doesn't lie or get embarrassed, so the results aren't unreliable.
- In a coke Vs pepsi test, pepsi won the experiment, but people prefer coke because a whole can is nicer than pepsi, which can be too sugary.
- The experiment was repeated but the people were told beforehand if they were about to drink Coke or Pepsi. This time coke won because it engages emotionally with us a lot more.
- Emotion is one of the keys to value
- Our brains react to fear more than they do to attraction, so lots of adverts use fear to change our behaviour

## 2. Product Placement, American Idol And Ford'S Multimillion Dollar Mistake
- Coming out with an original advert is risky to companies so they don't do it. So nobody stands out enough to be memorable.
- Nowadays it's harder to distinguish product integration (part of the plot of a movie) from product placement
- Coca cola and ford both paid over $20 mil to have product placement or advertising time
- Ray ban sales rose by 50% following Tom cruise wearing them on top gun (so did navy enrollment, by 500%)
- The best measure of an adverts effectiveness is how memorable it is
- Excessive product placement makes the product more memorable, it also inhibits the memory of other products
- Coke was the only memorable ad, because it was integrated into the TV show, ford was just a normal advert and lost money as a result
- product placement only works if it fits with the plot of the movie/show.

## 3. Mirror Neurones At Work
- mirror neurones are neurones that fire when you perform an action or when you see someone else perform the same action
- when watching cheaters experience pain, men felt pleasure while women felt empathy
- From a consumer perspective, guitar hero makes you feel like jagger, you like that so you buy one
- Dopamine is released when mirror neurones fire, and it's the most addictive substance in our bodies (pleasure drug)

## 4. Subliminal Messaging, Alive And Well
- Subliminal advertising = Subconscious messages conveyed by advertiser's to affect our actions
- Eg, putting an image of coca cola in a movie for 1/30th of a second
- Subliminal messages of smiling or angry faces affects our emotions and makes us want to pay more/less for something (happy = more)
- subliminal advertising has little to do with the product and a lot to do with our brain.
- Cigarette companies install "Marlborough motels" that convey subliminal messages because they can't advertise on TV
- By banning conventional cigarette ads, tabacco companies have been forced to evolve their advertising into the future
- subliminal cigarette ads have the same effect as blatant ones, but with subliminal ones you don't put up defences against them so they can sometimes be more effective

## 5. Ritual, Superstition And Why We Buy
- the line in a Corona thing started when a bartended lost a bet to serve a Corona with a lime in it
- associating products with rituals makes them more memorable
- there's a sense of stability in having a favourite coffee or shampoo etc, it makes us feel in control
- the ritual of collecting things makes us feel in control

## 6. Faith, Religion And Brands
- people pay large amounts of money to import holy Israeli dirt or Irish dirt or to buy holy water that has been blessed by a priest.
- 10 basic pillars of religion: sense of belonging, clear vision/mission, power over enemies, sensory appeal, storytelling, grandeur, evangelism, symbols, mystery, rituals.
- these 10 pillars can be easily likened to large companies whom advertise products to us
- sensory appeal: the sensory feel of a temple isn't all too different from getting into a Mercedes, the control of our emotions is the same
- power over enemies: coke Vs pepsi is the same as Jews Vs Christians
- storytelling: the Bible isn't dissimilar to the stories in adverts or Disney movies
- grandeur: Vatican city is the same idea as the bolagio hotel, big and awesome
- symbols: the cross and the dove are the same as company logos to us
- mystery: god being real compared to the secret coca cola recipe
- ritual: praying Vs slice of lime in a Corona
- smashable- if you smashed it you would still know it's brand. Clothes aren't smashable because the brand is the logo, a broken iPod is still an iPod, 2 drops of guinness is still Guinness
- strong brands Vs weak brands Vs religion experiment: strong brands cause more brain activity than weak ones.
- interestingly, strong brands and religious images cause the SAME brain activity - they elicit the same emotional response!

## 7. The Power Of Somatic Markers
- somatic marker = past life experiences that connect to a specific emotion and sometimes require a specific reaction
- Michelin star --> good --> Michelin tyres
- Andrex --> puppy --> soft --> buy
- basically any memorable positive event(s) you can relate to a product, or a negative experience to push you to need a product to prevent the anxiety
- ritalin and Adderall are sold because parents fear if their ADD kid doesn't concentrate he'll fail in life

## 8. Selling To Our Senses
- sensory branding - associating a combinations of senses with the brand
- images and smells are just as effective on their own, but when combined they're much more pleasurable
- the same is true for images and sounds
- obviously the scent and sight must fit together
- you react to smell more primally than sight/sound. It brings back memories without you having to think about it
- bakeries are put in supermarkets so the fresh bread makes you hungry do you buy more food you didn't plan on buying
- you don't have to notice the smell either, a lemony aroma will Subconscious make you do things in a cleaner manner
- feel is significant too, we tend to thing heavier things have higher quality which lead B and O to put aluminium (for no function) in their products to make them feel better quality
- colours have a huge effect on purchasing too, pink is associated with femininity and sensuality hence it's the colour of most women's underwear
- sound (in the form of jingles mostly) is a good way to be memorable as it can get stuck in your head
- a study they did shows that the Nokia ringtone is a negative somatic marker and is actually harming the brand
- Overall: senses affect our emotions, but complementry combinations of senses do it way better, making us more likely to buy

## 9. Neuromarketing And Predicting The Future
- Steve Jobs said segways would revolutionise the future, expecting 40,000 sales a month, in a few years it only sold 2,000 total.
- producers aren't good at predicting how consumers will react to a product launch
- conducted a TV show based experiment to see if neuromarketing could tell successful shows from unsuccessful ones
- the successful show engaged people much more and had a stronger emotional connection
- they said they hated quizmania but their brains say they loved it
- when it aired, the highest rated was most successful, the lowest rates was least successful and the middle rated was middle successful (from the brain scans)
- this shows we can use neuromarketing to see how successful a product will be before committing to all it's necessary processes (it can kinda predict the future)
- companies will swap focus groups for SST caps

## 10. Sex In Advertising
- roughly 1 in 5 adverts we see have sexual connotations
- vampire effect: sexual content in adverts sucks attention from the company and product toward the sexual nature, basically men don't care what the hot woman is selling they just stare at her tits
- this vampire effect also applies to using good looking people or celebrities in adverts, they distract you from the point of the advert - John classes smoking advert failed because people just saw funny John cleese and not "stop smoking"
- the US department of justice investigated kalvin Klein for breaching child pornography laws in some of its commercials (the one made to mimic low budget porn in motels) but he was never charged
- sex itself isn't what sells, it's the controversy surrounding it that gives the brand free publicity, that's what sells
- The shock factor of seeing softcore porn on a billboard makes the advert more memorable
- On the whole we are more receptive to ordinary people in adverts who we feel are similar to ourselves. They are more relatable and the realness of these people creates authenticity and we feel we can trust them
- mirror neurones however make us feel as sexy and attractive as the people in the boxers we are about to buy.
- the Gillette strategy is targeting advertising to who's going to buy the product, most Gillette razors are bought by men's wives, because the wives want their men to look like the guy in the advert
- to maintain the shock factor, it's possible that adverts will begin to get more and more sexual and eventually it will backtrack and all sexual advertising will be subliminal and suggedtive

## 11. The Future Of Marketing And Advertising
- When using an fMRI to study pleasure in the brain when people tasted some of different tastes and prices, the same wine was presented twice with different price tags and they found that higher price increases the pleasure of consumption
- fear scares people away if it feeds on general anxieties we have, but if you target specific insecurities that can easily be fixed it is a very powerful marketing instrument
- when we feel out of control we seek solid foundations and become more dependent on dopamine, when were more dependent on dopamine we tend to seek out more "stuff" to satisfy our dopamine need
- we value special things more, wether it is rational or not. I give you a rock and you don't care, but I tell you it's from the moon and now it's a very valuable thing to you, the rock hasn't changed at all though.
- humans brands like Paris Hilton and Richard Branson are likely to increase in popularity in the future he thinks, as they are 24 hour brands

## 12. Good Times, Bad Times
- the 2008 recession had significant shock factor and became a somatic marker to many consumers, telling them that it's a bad idea to consume at the levels they used to.
- Fear of losing job/income stopped Americans buying cars, so hayundai said that if you lose your job within a year of buying a car, you can return it, sales went up 33%
- he argues the crisis of 2008 was necessary to stop us spending beyond our means and keep us in financial order
- discounts actually make you buy less, when you buy a shirt at 70% off, when it's at full price, maybe you would buy it, but not when it's value to you is now 70% off, you won't buy at full price. On average it takes 7 years for the value of the product to recover from a discounting! 7 years!
- studies have also shown that we become addicted to discounts, searching for the lowest prices and best value becomes obsessive
- the price of a good is valued relative to its peers/nearest rivals, not the absolute monetary value
- more choice leads to less purchasing, as more choice makes choices harder

title: Black Box Thinking
author: Matthew Syed
content:
Black boxes are the tracking machines in planes that record data. The aviation industry has got really good at tweaking work processes to avoid failure by using the information from these black boxes. Black Box Thinking is about taking information from different areas of a business (or your life) and using it to tweak your actions in the direction of constant improvement, just like pilots. 

## Data We Can't See
- Commander said armour the wings as they are most hit in the returning planes
- Wald said that the planes that did not return were hit in the cockpit and so they should armour the cockpit
- The unseen data (non returning planes) proved vital in the success of the fleet in the future

## Pattern Recognition
- Pattern 2 4 6
- You'll only figure it out if you try to disprove your theory
- Its actually ascending numbers

## Preventing Progress In UK Legal System
- Its illegal to conduct studies on how UK juries make decisions
- "if people find out how juries operate they may lose confidence in the system"
- Quantity and producing work do more for quality than perfectionism ever will - so take a bottom up approach and iterate to perfection. Don't try to hit it first time

## Marginal Gains
- Born out of an efficient open feedback loop
- They take you to local optimal points
- Global optimal points require innovation that marginal gains cannot provide (think of the diagram and moving incrementally)

## Creativity
- Is a response to a problem (Dyson)
- Dispute and contradiction fuel creativity
- Innovation alone doesn't cut it, you need discipline to make your idea into something (Hoover's had been patented before Dyson turned up)

## Grit
- The best predictor of who will excel at West point, the toughest army barracks in the US
- Resilience

## Growth Mindset
- Fixed mindset takes failure as meaning youre not good at something
- Growth mindset will take the same failure and use it to improve

## Combining Top Down And Bottom Up
- Get 100 groups using theory (top down) to solve a problem
- Every time a breakthrough is made iterate it to all groups
- repeat

## Pre Mortem
- Before you have failed, assume you already have
- Come up with ideas as to why this hypothetical failure happened
- Changes the way you view the problem
